conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the relationship between the voltage and current in an ideal transformer. The primary and secondary sides of the transformer have the same voltage, but the current is inversely proportional to the turns ratio.
The reading of the ideal ammeter is 1.4 A.
The reading of the ideal voltmeter is 10 V.
The resistance R1 = R2 = R3 = 50 Ω.

Use the formula for the voltage ratio in an ideal transformer: V1/V2 = n1/n2 where V1 is the voltage on the primary side, V2 is the voltage on the secondary side, and n1 and n2 are the turns ratio of the primary and secondary coils, respectively.
The voltage V1 on the primary side is: V1 = 1.4 × n1.
The voltage V2 on the secondary side is: V2 = 10.

premise: Using the voltage ratio V1/V2 = n1/n2.
Substitute n1 = 10n2 into the voltage ratio equation.
Calculate the turns ratio n1 : n2 = 100 : 10.
